column2: Bilingual Dictionary Construction with Transliteration Filtering
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest page-top headchar-capital above-double-space above-line-space

column2: John Richardson † , Toshiaki Nakazawa ‡ , Sadao Kurohashi †
column3: page=0 xpos=1 ypos=0 single-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space symbol-dagger symbol-dagger headchar-capital above-double-space above-line-space

column3: page=0 xpos=1 ypos=1 single-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail symbol-atmark headchar-lower above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Abstract
column3: page=0 xpos=4 ypos=1 single-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space string-abstract headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: In this paper we present a bilingual transliteration lexicon of 170K Japanese-English technical terms in the scientiﬁc
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified font-smallest hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: domain. Translation pairs are extracted by ﬁltering a large list of transliteration candidates generated automatically
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified font-smallest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: from a phrase table trained on parallel corpora. Filtering uses a novel transliteration similarity measure based on a
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified font-smallest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: discriminative phrase-based machine translation approach. We demonstrate that the extracted dictionary is accurate and
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified font-smallest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: of high recall (F <sub>1</sub> -score 0.8). Our lexicon contains not only single words but also multi-word expressions, and is freely
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified font-smaller aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: available. Our experiments focus on Katakana-English lexicon construction, however it would be possible to apply the
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified font-smallest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: proposed methods to transliteration extraction for a variety of language pairs.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period column-bottom above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Keywords: transliteration, lexicon, Katakana
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column right-indent font-smallest column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space string-keyword headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 1. Introduction
column3: page=0 xpos=1 ypos=3 left-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: A large lexicon of technical terms is important for
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: many natural language processing applications, partic-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ularly machine translation. The aim of this research
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: is to generate a large Japanese-English dictionary for
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the scientiﬁc domain.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: The great majority of technical terms in Japanese are
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: transliterations of English words. It is therefore an in-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: teresting option to consider designing a system specif-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ically for transliteration extraction, as this allows us
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to improve the accuracy greatly by making use of
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: a transliteration model, while sacriﬁcing only mini-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: mal coverage. Although we concentrate on Japanese-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: English in this paper, our model could easily be ex-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tended to generate dictionaries for other languages
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: that contain many transliterations, such as Arabic, Ko-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: rean and Russian.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: Transliterations in the Japanese language are written
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: with a special writing system (‘Katakana’) used pri-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: marily for transliterations, and this makes it relatively
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: simple to ﬁnd likely transliterations. There can be a
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: number of spelling variations for the same transliter-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ation. For example both konpyuuta コンピュータ and
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: konpyuutaa コンピューター are valid transliterations of
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: ‘computer’. There is however often a preferred spelling.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: Our method is to use a discriminative extension to
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-capital

column2: phrase-based statistical machine translation (PBSMT)
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to ﬁlter a list of transliteration candidates. This model
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: is able to score transliterations with high accuracy.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The candidates to be ﬁltered are generated automat-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: ically by using a standard PBSMT system to extract
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: phrase pairs from a parallel corpus.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: It can be observed that alignment accuracy is relatively
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: high for transliterations compared to other words, as
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: a result of their rarity and relatively low ambiguity.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: We believe therefore that the use of a phrase table is a
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: good choice for a source of high quality transliteration
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: candidates. Another motivation for the use of phrase-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen column-bottom

column2: __Figure 1__
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column centered left-indent right-indent box column-top figure-area above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Figure 1: Example of Katakana–English translitera-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space string-figure headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion phrase alignment.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: based SMT is that it is possible to consider multi-word
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower

column2: expressions.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2. Transliteration Model
column3: page=0 xpos=6 ypos=5 right-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: We begin by constructing a transliteration model that
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: can be used to score candidate transliteration pairs. A
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: standard PBSMT decoder is designed to ﬁnd the best
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: translation of an input sentence, however we require a
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: discriminative model to measure the likelihood that a
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: candidate translation pair is correct. We therefore de-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: sign a discriminative ﬁlter that can make use of phrase
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: translation probabilities.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The model learns probabilities P (f | e) of obtaining
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: the character sequence f = f <sub>1</sub> , ..., f m by transliter-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ating the sequence e = e <sub>1</sub> , ..., e n . We wish to learn
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: probabilities such as those shown in Table 1.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The probabilities are learned from a set of translitera-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion pairs using a grapheme-based machine translation
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: model. We model transliteration as a phrase-based
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: machine translation task on a character rather than
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: word level, treating character groups as phrases. The
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: model is trained by learning phrase alignments such
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: as that shown in Figure 1 from a training corpus (for
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: details see Section 4.1.).
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The ﬁeld of phrase-based SMT has been well studied
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital column-bottom above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=0 xpos=4 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only page-bottom

column2: __Table 1__
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=-1 left-column centered left-indent right-indent box page-top table-area above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Table 1: Examples of transliteration probabilities from
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space string-table headchar-capital

column2: PBSMT model.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: and there exists a standard toolset enabling the con-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: struction of such a model. Character alignment was
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: performed by GIZA++ (Och and Ney, 2003) with the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: ‘grow-diag-ﬁnal’ heuristic for training. We used the de-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line tailchar-hiphen

column2: fault conﬁguration of the Moses (Koehn et al., 2007)
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: tuning pipeline with the distortion limit set to 1 (as
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: transliteration requires monotonic alignment) to gen-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: erate a phrase table for transliteration. The phrase
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: translation probabilities could then be extracted di-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: rectly from the phrase table.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2.1. Scoring Metric
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space above-line-space

column2: In order to measure the likelihood that an input word
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: pair is a correct transliteration, we deﬁne a translit-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: eration likelihood score. This score makes use of the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: probabilities (such as in Table 1) of a Japanese charac-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ter sequence f given some English character sequence
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: e, which we denote as P (f | e).
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column right-indent font-largest aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The score of a candidate pair is calculated by con-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: sidering each possible segmentation of the English
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: and Japanese words s and t into n character groups
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: s <sub>1</sub> , ..., s n and t 1 , ..., t n , then calculating the product
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: <sup>of</sup> <sup>the</sup> <sup>translation</sup> <sup>probabilities</sup> ∏ of each corresponding
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-super

column2: character sequence, i.e. <sup>n</sup> <sub>i=1</sub> P (t i | s i ). It is neces-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: sary to ﬁnd the optimal segmentation a (containing
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: |a| character groups), giving the ﬁnal score as:
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column right-indent font-largest aligned-line shorter-tail tailchar-colon above-double-space above-line-space

column2: ∏ <sup>|a|</sup>
column3: page=1 xpos=1 ypos=6 left-column left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space

column2: max P (t <sub>a,i</sub> | s a,i ) (1)
column3: page=1 xpos=1 ypos=6 left-column left-indent font-largest hanged-line longer-tail headchar-lower

column2: a
column3: page=1 xpos=1 ypos=7 left-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower
page=1 xpos=1 ypos=7 left-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line longer-tail headchar-lower above-double-space above-line-space

column2: In contrast to HMM-based models, we do not consider
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: the transition probability P (s <sub>i</sub> | s i−1 ) as it is given that
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the candidates are actual words (they were extracted
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: from a bilingual corpus). That is to say we make the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: assumption that P (t <sub>i</sub> | s i ) does not depend on s i−1
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: or t <sub>i−1</sub> , which in practice is true if the segments are
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: suﬃciently long.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Naturally the set of all possible segment pairs is very
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: large, and therefore some of the longer and rarer char-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: acter sequences do not appear in the training data.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: These segment pairs will yield zero transliteration
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: probabilities. This issue is unavoidable, however it is
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: not such a serious problem as the model considers the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: combination of shorter character groups. This achieves
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower column-bottom

column2: an eﬀect similar to backoﬀ and interpolation smooth-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column full-justified column-top headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ing methods used in language modeling.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2.2. Finding an Optimal Segmentation
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: In Equation 1 we require the evaluation of every pos-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: sible segmentation. It is however impractical to use
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: brute-force search for long candidates, as the number
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: of possible segmentations is of the order O(4 <sup>n</sup> ) for a
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: candidate pair of length (m, n) (m > n).
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: To improve the eﬃciency of score computation, we de-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: signed a k-best greedy segmentation algorithm. Begin-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ning with the entire words e and f , we ﬁnd the k-best
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: preﬁx segment pairs (e <sub>1,1</sub> , f 1,1 ), ..., (e 1,k , f 1,k ). The re-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: mainder of the words are then split in a similar way
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: by ﬁnding the k-best preﬁx segments. This is repeated
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: until the candidate pair has been fully segmented. See
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: Figure 2 for an illustration of this algorithm.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail string-figure headchar-capital tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: The complexity of the segmentation problem can now
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: be reduced to O(k <sup>n</sup> ) by considering the k-best preﬁxes
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: at each step or O(kn) by keeping a global k-best list.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: While this is an approximate algorithm, it will always
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: give a lower bound, which is suitable for ﬁltering out
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: unlikely candidates. This bound can be improved by
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: using larger k.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: In a practical implementation we can further in-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: crease the speed by using the cutoﬀ C that
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: will later be used for ﬁltering the candidates.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Since it is always the case that score(t <sub>1</sub> , ..., t i |
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: s <sub>1</sub> , ..., s i ) ≥ score(t 1 , ..., t i , t i+1 |s 1 , ..., s i , s i+1 ) (since
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: P (t <sub>i+1</sub> |s i+1 ) ≤ 1), we can skip any partial segmen-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tations with scores ≤ C. This works comfortably for
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: words of practical length (under ~40 characters).
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 3. Filtering
column3: page=1 xpos=6 ypos=5 right-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: We now introduce our ﬁltering process. We ﬁrst gen-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: erate a large list of candidate translation pairs, then
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: ﬁlter these candidates with the transliteration likeli-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line tailchar-hiphen

column2: hood score deﬁned in Section 2.1..
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: The candidates are generated automatically by using
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: the standard PBSMT pipeline to align and extract
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: translation phrase pairs from a large parallel corpus.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: We consider only the phrase pairs containing translit-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: erations in the Japanese side by removing entries that
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: contain non-Katakana characters. Examples of ex-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tracted candidates are shown in Table 2. A beneﬁt of
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: using phrase-based SMT is that we are able to consider
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: multi-word expressions and not only single words.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: Finally, the dictionary is created by ﬁltering the can-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: didates by score. We take C = 0.1 as the cutoﬀ, in-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: cluding all candidates scoring higher than this thresh-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: old. For any given word we keep all possible trans-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: lations that score higher than the cutoﬀ in order to
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: include all valid spelling variations. This is important
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: for Japanese, where there can be a number of such
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: variations appearing in unedited texts, such as on the
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: web. The value 0.1 was chosen to ensure a very high
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: precision, however this could be reduced if such a clean
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: dictionary is not required. The ease of selecting the re-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: quired precision/recall is a beneﬁt of this approach.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period column-bottom above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=1 xpos=4 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only page-bottom

column2: 4. Dictionary Construction
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The aim of this research is to provide a method of
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: generating a large bilingual lexicon that is simple to
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: implement. We constructed such a lexicon, a dictio-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: nary of Katakana-English scientiﬁc terminology, in or-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: der to evaluate the proposed method. The dictionary
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: was evaluated based on its coverage and accuracy of
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: entries.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.1. Data Sets
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The data used to train the transliteration model in Sec-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion 2. consisted of Katakana-English dictionary en-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tries and aligned pairs of Japanese-English Wikipedia
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: article titles (69K entries in total).
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: The phrase candidates for ﬁltering were extracted from
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: a large parallel corpus of research paper title pairs pro-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: vided by the Japan Science and Technology Agency.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The corpus contained 24M parallel title pairs, gen-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: erating 7M Katakana-English phrase candidates after
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: removing entries that contained non-Katakana char-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: acters.

column2: 4.2. Results and Evaluation
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Using the parallel corpus above to generate candidates,
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-comma

column2: we were able to build a dictionary containing 170K
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: entries. The extracted dictionary can be obtained for
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower column-bottom

column2: free <sup>1</sup> . Some examples of extracted terms can be seen
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified font-largest column-top headchar-lower

column2: in Table 3.
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: In order to evaluate the quality and coverage of our dic-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tionary, we created a test set of candidate word pairs.
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: We selected 1000 candidates generated from the pa-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: per abstracts corpus at random and tagged them as
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: ‘translation’ or ‘not-translation’ by hand. The extrac-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion algorithm used to generate the full dictionary was
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: run on this test set and the extracted lexicon tested
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: against the reference labels.
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The system achieved a precision of 1.000 and recall
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: of 0.667 (F <sub>1</sub> -score 0.8) using the cutoﬀ C = 0.1. By
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: changing the value of C it would be possible if required
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to increase the recall by sacriﬁcing some precision. The
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: highest F <sub>1</sub> -score was around 0.85 with C ≈ 0.005. See
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: Figure 3 for the precision-recall curve.
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail string-figure headchar-capital tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: been one of the most studied areas in the ﬁeld of Nat-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ural Language Processing in recent years, especially
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: with the hope of harnessing the vast sum of data avail-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: able on the web. A variety of approaches have been
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: proposed, most of which focus on the extraction of
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: generic lexicons, however in this paper we focus on
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower above-double-space above-line-space

column2: the subtask of transliteration extraction.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column right-indent column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: There has been much work on the task of transliter-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: ation generation, i.e. predicting the correct translit-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: eration of some given input word. This research be-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: gan with the introduction of Machine Transliteration
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: (Knight and Graehl, 1998), which has progressed to
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line year

column2: consider a variety of methods ranging from simple edit
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: distance and noisy-channel models (Brill et al., 2001)
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: to conditional random ﬁelds (Ganesh et al., 2008) and
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: ﬁnite state automata (Noeman and Madkour, 2010).
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail year tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The PBSMT-based transliteration system described in
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: Section 2. was implemented as speciﬁed in previous
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: work on transliteration extraction such as Richardson
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: et al. (2013) (Japanese and Korean), Matthews (2007)
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: (Chinese and Arabic), and Antony et al. (2010) (Kan-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line year tailchar-hiphen

column2: nada).
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The task of identifying and extracting correct translit-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: eration pairs however is less explored. This classiﬁca-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion problem is the key to using ﬁltering for bilingual
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: lexicon extraction, and we have proposed a novel ap-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: proach to score transliteration candidates.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period column-bottom

column2: 6. Conclusion and Future Work
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest column-top itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: In this paper we have introduced an approach to ex-
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tracting a large dictionary of Japanese-English techni-
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: cal terms using a transliteration-based approach. The
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: core of our method is a discriminative transliteration
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: model based on the framework of statistical machine
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: translation.
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: Analysis of our extraction lexicon show that
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: transliteration-based ﬁltering is able to generate re-
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: sources with high precision and recall. It is possible to
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: extract not only single words, as is the case in many
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: previous studies, but also multi-word expressions. An
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: additional beneﬁt of our approach is that is it simple
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to adjust the required precision/recall ratio by setting
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the cutoﬀ.
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: In the future we would like to extend our system to
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: extract dictionaries for other language pairs, such as
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: Chinese-English, using a similar transliteration model.
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-period

column2: The identiﬁcation of transliterations is non-trivial for
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: some languages, so this is a further consideration to be
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: made in future work. It is also important to consider
column3: page=3 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower column-bottom above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=3 xpos=4 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only page-bottom

column2: how to generate as large a candidate list as possible,
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified page-top headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: ideally from non-parallel data, as this is the main fac-
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tor in determining the size of the extracted dictionary.
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space
